Award.AwardTitle: Research: Badges for college credit (BCC): Motivating learning in informal science programs through a digital badge system

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Badges for College Credit project designs and researches:

1. a digital badge system that leads to college credit as the context for investigating how to integrate badges with learning programs,
2. how to assess learning associated with badges, and
3. how badges facilitate learning pathways and contribute to science identity formation.

The project is one of the first efforts to develop a system to associate informal science learning with college credit. The project will partner with three regional informal science institutions, the Pacific Science Center, the Future of Flight, and the Seattle of Aquarium, that will facilitate activities for participants that are linked to informal science learning and earning badges.

The project uses the iRemix platform, a social learning platform, as a delivery system to direct participants to materials, resources, and activities that support the learning goals of the project. Badges earned within the system can be exported to the Mozilla Open Badges platform. Participants can earn three types of badges, automatic (based on participation), community (based on contributions to building the online community), and skill (based on mastery of science and communication) badges.

Using a learning ecologies framework, the project will investigate multiple influences on how and why youth participate in science learning and making decisions. Project research uses a qualitative and quantitative approach, including observations, interviews, case studies, surveys, and learning analytics data, and data analytics. Project evaluation will focus on the nature and function of the collaboration, and on the scale-up aspects of the innovation and expansion, by: (1) analyzing and documenting effective procedures,and optimal contexts for the dissemination of the model and (2) by analyzing the collaboration between informal science organizations and higher education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project proposed to design a digital badge system that awarded college credit to high school students engaged in informal science learning programs. The goals of the project included (1) to design learning pathways that connect informal science education programs to institutions of higher education, and (2) to design badge systems that systematically support the development of expertise, identity, and social participation within each informal science program. This was a partnership between the University of Washington Bothell, Pacific Science Center/Mercer Slough Environmental Education Center, The Seattle Aquarium, and the Future of Flight. Each informal science institution had at least one program where high school-aged youth were engaged in some aspect of deep STEM learning  (ecology/conservation, marine biology/conservation, or material science engineering). We partnered each informal science institution with a faculty member at the University of Washington Bothell in the appropriate disciplinary area to co-design badge pathways and accompanying badge criteria that represent equivalent material covered in a college-level course. At the same time, the university faculty received approval for courses at the university for which qualifying students receive credit. Students who completed all requisite badges received credit at the University of Washington for the respective course.

Learning through co-design: We engaged in two types of co-design in the project. In the first, with Pacific Science Center and the Future of Flight, co-design involved informal science practitioners, university researchers, and university faculty in appropriate STEM disciplines. With the Seattle Aquarium, co-design also involved participating youth in the program. In both implementations of co-design, we found that careful consideration is required to design, develop and implement a badge system that reflects the learning outcomes of the respective programs. In addition, with youth co-design, we found that without youth participation products such as digital badges may represent program values from practitioner and faculty perspectives while overlooking important but subtle aspects of learning and program experiences that are highly valued by youth.

 

We found that the process of co-design was powerful for Informal Science Education practitioners to clarify the program intent, the purpose of specific activities, and how to assess youth learning and achievements within their programs. At the same time, it was a positive recognition by both academic faculty and ISE staff that much of what was being asked of youth was of sufficient quality and rigor to warrant college credit.

 

Badges as motivation: In keeping with existing literature that critiques the use of badge systems in education, we have found that unexamined, badges and badge systems on their own do not provide enough motivation for youth to engage in a program. Youth come to informal science learning programs for other reasons and remain engaged for reasons not necessarily attributable to receiving badges. However, badges, if designed correctly, can make rich and complex learning pathways accessible and learning criteria for learning visible. How badge criteria are articulated also impacts youth engagement with badge systems.

We also found that program structure affects motivation for earning badges. In non-cohort modeled programs where youth progress through the program at individual rates, badges did not demonstrate to be motivating factors in youth engagement in the program. In cohort modeled programs where a community of youth completed all of the same tasks at the same time, the badges also did not prove to be a motivating factor in youths’ decision to participate in the program. However, in cohort modeled programs where a community of youth was able to select different pathways of badges and different outcomes, badges proved to be an engaging system that allowed youth to express individual interest while still receiving the support and sense of community of a cohort model.  

Badge platform features and functionalities: Online platforms that support badging and achievement systems vary in their features and functionality. This variation determines, to some degree, the design of the educational programs using these platforms. Through the course of this project, we have demonstrated how platforms are not neutral tools: they afford and constrain badge functionality that shapes and determine learning and pathways in significant ways. For example, the LRNG platform organizes experiences into “playlists” which each culminate in a single badge. Playlists are comprised of sets of experiences: digital XPs which are activities that take place strictly online and local XPs which are experiences that take strictly offline. The configuration of open-ended XPs allows for designers of badge systems to integrate a wider variety of activities into a single badge. This configuration of badging systems is in line with the design principles articulated through our research: the quality of the activities associated with badges is a contributing factor to the success of a badging system supporting learning and identity development. The “grainsize” of activities that can be badged has implications on how personalized or tailored the learning experiences can be to individual learners.
